Accessed November 1, 2007.</ref> ([[county seat]]){{GR|6}} of [[Rutland County, Vermont|Rutland County]], [[Vermont]], [[United States]]. As of the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]], the city had a total population of 16,495.<ref name="Census 2010">{{cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov| title=Race, Hispanic or Latino, Age, and Housing Occupancy: 2010 Census Redistricting Data (Public Law 94-171) Summary File (QT-PL), Rutland city, Vermont| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau, American FactFinder 2| accessdate=November 1, 2011}}</ref> Rutland is located approximately {{convert|65|mi|km}} north of [[Massachusetts]] and {{convert|20|mi|km}} east of [[New York|New York state]]. Rutland is the third largest city in [[Vermont]]. It is surrounded by the town of [[Rutland (town), Vermont|Rutland]], which is a separate municipality. The [[Rutland Downtown Historic District|downtown area]] of the city is listed as a historic district on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].
==History== [[File:Merchants' Row, Looking North, Rutland, VT.jpg|thumb|left|Merchants' Row in 1907]] It began on [[Otter Creek (Vermont)|Otter Creek]] in the early 19th century as a small hamlet called Mill Village in Rutland, the surrounding town named by Governor [[Benning Wentworth]] in 1761 after [[John Manners, 3rd Duke of Rutland]].<ref name="books.google.com">[http://books.google.com/books?id=OcoMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&dq=coolidge+mansfield+history+description+new+england+1859&source=web&ots=cUndZkVSIF&sig=tIIdKdnVIkM1ULWZYVqH4J03FbE&hl=en#PPA891,M1 A. J. Coolidge & J. B. Mansfield, ''A History and Description of New England;'' Boston, Massachusetts 1859]</ref> In the early 19th century, small high-quality [[marble]] deposits were discovered in Rutland, and in the 1830s a large deposit of nearly solid marble was found in what is now [[West Rutland, Vermont|West Rutland]]. By the 1840s, small firms had begun excavations, but marble [[quarry|quarries]] proved profitable only after the [[railroad]] arrived in 1851. At the same time, the famous quarries of [[Carrara]] in [[Tuscany]], [[Italy]], grew largely unworkable because of their extreme depth, allowing Rutland to become one of the world's leading marble producers.<ref name="books.google.com"/>
This fueled enough growth and investment that in 1886 the center of town incorporated as Rutland village. Most of the town was split off as West Rutland and [[Proctor, Vermont|Proctor]], which contained the bulk of the marble quarries. Rutland City was incorporated as Vermont's third city on November 18, 1892. The new city's first mayor was [[John A. Mead]], who served only one term in 1893.<ref>109th Annual Report Fiscal Year July 1, 2000 to June 30, 2001 City of Rutland, Vermont</ref>
In 1894, the nation's first [[polio]] outbreak was identified in the Rutland area. 132 people from the Rutland area were affected. Seven died. 110 others suffered some paralysis for life. 55 were from the city itself.<ref>{{cite book | author = Remsen, Nancy |title = Polio marker moved to public spot | publisher = Burlington Free Press | date = September 29, 2007}}</ref> [[File:Berwick House, Rutland, VT.jpg|thumb|left|The Berwick House in 1907]]
In 1903, a Rutland City ordinance restricting the carrying of firearms led to the [[Vermont Supreme Court]]'s decision in ''State v. Rosenthal'', thereby establishing protection for the carrying of firearms without permit or license, what has become known as "Vermont Carry".<ref>http://www.guncite.com/court/state/55a610.html</ref> Nonetheless, Rutland had a similar ordinance in place as late as 1998,<ref>http://www.vtlp.org/main/media/news/pr980622-RutlandGunRights.html</ref> at which point it was challenged and eventually removed, and there have been reports from residents of police harassment over openly carrying firearms as recently as June 2008.<ref>http://opencarry.mywowbb.com/forum53/11480.html</ref>
The closing of the marble quarries in the area in the 1980s and 1990s cost the area jobs.
==Geography== Rutland is located at {{Coord|43|36|32|N|72|58|47|W|type:city}} (43.60889, -72.97972).{{GR|1}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|7.67|sqmi}}, of which {{convert|7.6|sqmi}} is land and {{convert|0.04|sqmi}}, or 0.52%, is water. Rutland is drained by [[Otter Creek (Vermont)|Otter Creek]], Moon Brook, Tenney Brook, East Creek and Mussey Brook.
==Transportation== ===Rail=== [[Rutland (Amtrak station)|Rutland's railroad station]] is the terminal station for [[Amtrak]]'s [[Ethan Allen Express]], which provides daily 5.5 hour service to and from [[New York City]].<ref>Ethan Allen Express, Amtrak Timetable, 2013, http://www.amtrak.com/ethan-allen-express-train</ref> In January, 2013 Vermont Governor [[Peter Shumlin]] proposed extending the Ethan Allen Express from Rutland to [[Burlington, Vermont]], the state's largest city. The proposal would create a [[regional rail|regional rail corridor]] connecting Albany, Saratoga Springs, Rutland and Burlington and their combined metro populations of around 1.25 million inhabitants.<ref>Thursday, January 31, 2013, Vermont governor seeks more Amtrak service, Written by Douglas John Bowen, http://www.railwayage.com/index.php/passenger/intercity/vermont-governor-seeks-more-amtrak-service.html?channel=41</ref>
===Bus=== {{Main|Marble Valley Regional Transit District}} Rutland is home to "The Bus", run by [[Marble Valley Regional Transit District]], a local bus system costing $0.50 per person per ride ($0.25 for discount qualified riders), and $1-2 for out-of-town commuter and connector buses, with other expenses covered largely by taxpayers. Five local routes currently serve the city, along with other commuter routes serving the nearby towns of [[Fair Haven, Vermont|Fair Haven]], [[Manchester, Vermont|Manchester]], [[Middlebury, Vermont|Middlebury]] (via connection with ACTR bus in Brandon), and [[Proctor, Vermont|Proctor]]. 2 winter tourist geared buses also go to and from [[Okemo Mountain]] in [[Ludlow (town), Vermont|Ludlow]] and [[Killington Ski Resort]], with the latter being known as the Diamond Express. Both of these buses run year round. "The Bus" was free prior to 2007, when the 50 cents fare was added to control the added gas expenses.{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}} MVRTD is housed in the downtown Marble Valley Regional Transit Center. [[File:The Bus Rutland.jpg|thumb|The Bus, downtown Rutland]]
===Air=== The [[Rutland Southern Vermont Regional Airport]] is located just south of the city, in [[Clarendon, Vermont|North Clarendon]]. The airport offers daily flights to Boston operated by [[Cape Air]]. ===Car/Truck=== Rutland is the largest city in Vermont that is not located on, or near, either of the state's two major Interstate highways. [[U.S. Route 4]] and [[U.S. Route 7]] intersect in Rutland and are the two main routes into the city. U.S. 7 connects Rutland with [[Manchester, Vermont|Manchester]] and [[Bennington, Vermont|Bennington]] to the south, and with [[Middlebury, Vermont|Middlebury]] and [[Burlington, Vermont|Burlington]] to the north. To the east of Rutland, U.S. 4 travels through [[Killington, Vermont|Killington]] and [[Woodstock, Vermont|Woodstock]] on its way toward [[New Hampshire]]. To the west, U.S. 4 has been rebuilt as a 4-lane freeway to the [[New York]] state line, a distance of just over {{convert|18|mi|km}}. It is currently the only limited-access freeway to serve Rutland. The former route of U.S. 4, which runs parallel to the freeway portion, is now signed as [[Vermont Route 4A]].
==Demographics== {{USCensusPop | 1800= 2125 | 1810= 2379 | 1820= 2586 | 1830= 2753 | 1840= 2708 | 1850= 3715 | 1860= 7577 | 1870= 9834 | 1880= 12140 | 1890= 11760 | 1900= 11499 | 1910= 13456 | 1920= 14954 | 1930= 17315 | 1940= 17082 | 1950= 17659 | 1960= 18325 | 1970= 19293 | 1980= 18436 | 1990= 18230 | 2000= 17292 | 2010= 16495 | estimate= | estyear= }}
As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 17,292 people, 7,452 households, and 4209 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 2254.5 people per square mile (870.3/km<sup>2</sup>). There were 7,452 housing units at an average density of 94.49/sq mi (289.0/km<sup>2</sup>). The racial makeup of the city was 98.6% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|White]], 0.7% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|African American]], 0.7% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Native American]], 0.6% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Asian]], 0.1% [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Pacific Islander]], 0.3% from [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|other races]], and 0.9% from two or more races. [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Hispanic]] or [[Race and ethnicity in the United States Census|Latino]] of any race were 0.9% of the population.
There were 7,452 households out of which 21.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 39.8% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 12.5% had a female householder with no husband present, and 43.5% were non-families. 36.1% of all households were made up of individuals and 13.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.22 and the average family size was 2.80.
In the city the population was spread out with 22.7% under the age of 18, 7.8% from 18 to 24, 28.9% from 25 to 44, 22.4% from 45 to 64, and 18.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 39.3 years. For every 100 females there were 89.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 86.5 males.
==Economy== One measure of economic activity is retail sales. Rutland stood third in the state in 2007 with $321.6 million.<ref>{{cite book | author = McLean, Dan |title = Retail Sales by the numbers | publisher = Burlington Free Press | date = July 13, 2008}}</ref>
===Personal income=== The median income for a household in the city was $30,478, and the median income for a family was $41,561. Males had a median income of $29,457 versus $23,688 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $17,075. 15.4% of the population and 10.3% of families were below the poverty line. Out of the total people living in poverty, 30.1% are under the age of 18 and 10.5% are 65 or older.
===Industry=== Major area employers are [[Rutland Regional Medical Center]], [[General Electric Aircraft Engines|General Electric]] (GE), [[OMYA]] Central Vermont Public Service and Carris Reels. GE employed 975 workers in 2010.<ref>{{Cite news | first=John | last=Briggs | title=Sky's the limit | url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/article/20100823/NEWS01/100821005/Sky-s-the-limit-for-Vermont-s-aerospace-industry| work= | publisher=Burlington Free Press | location=Burlington, Vermont | pages= 1B,12B | date=23 August 2010 | accessdate=}}</ref> [[Casella Waste Systems]] is the second largest private employer (behind GE Aircraft), employing 583 employees at their headquarters on Green Hill Lane.<ref>{{cite web|title=REDC Major Employers|url=http://www.rutlandeconomy.com/workmajoremployees.php|work=Rutland Economic Development Corporation|accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref>
Recently, a {{convert|1|acre|m2|adj=on}} area of land downtown, known as "the pit", is slated for development. The new office building is planned to hold offices, education and civic space.
A judge on the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] holds the Vermont seat here.<!---could probably be worded better. This is not pertain to the government of Rutland, per se, but is an important function within the city---><!---may be federal district judge here too--->
==Culture== [[File:Ethnic Festival 062a.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Ethnic Festival in 2008]] The downtown section contains the Rutland Free Library,<ref>[http://www.rutlandfree.org/ Rutland Free Library]</ref> the Paramount Theater<ref>[http://www.paramountvt.org/ Paramount Theater]</ref> and Merchant's Row, a restored street dating back to the mid-19th century. 108 buildings in downtown Rutland are listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. Rutland also has the {{convert|275|acre|ha|sing=on}} Pine Hill Park<ref>[http://www.pinehillpark.org/ Pine Hill Park]</ref> offering mountain biking, hiking, and other outdoor recreation. At the park's entrance is the Flip Side Skatepark,<ref>[http://www.flipsidepark.com/ Flipside Skate Park]</ref> municipally operated in an open-sided closed roof arena at the Giorgetti Athletic Complex. Nearby in the town of [[Rutland (town), Vermont|Rutland]] is the Diamond Run Mall, a shopping mall anchored by [[Kmart]], [[Sears]], and [[JCPenney]], with other stores including [[American Eagle Outfitters]], [[RadioShack]], [[Claire's]] [[Maurice's]] and many others. <ref>[http://diamondrunmall.com/directory.html Diamond Run Mall directory]</ref> At 525,000 square feet, it is the second largest mall in Vermont, boasting over 55 shops. The Spartan Arena, home to the [[Castleton State College]] hockey teams, is also at the Diamond Run Mall.<ref>[http://diamondrunmall.com/about.html Diamond Run Mall about page]</ref>
'''Summer events in Rutland include:''' *Art in the Park and Friday Night Live *The Ethnic Festival *A Farmer's Market in downtown Rutland's Depot Park *The Summer Concert Series *In 2013, from August 15 to 18, Rutland will host the annual convention of the Red Knights International Firefighters Motorcycle Club, bringing over 600 motorcyclists from 6 countries to town.
The [[Rutland Halloween Parade]] has taken place annually since 1960. In the early 1970s, the Rutland Halloween Parade was used as the setting of a number of superhero [[comic books]], including ''Batman'' #237, ''Justice League of America'' #103, ''Freedom Fighters'' #6, ''Amazing Adventures'' #16, ''Avengers'' #83, and ''The Mighty Thor'' #207. The parade celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2009.<ref>[http://www.rutlandherald.com/article/20091025/NEWS/910259998 "Rutland scares up pride with 50-year Halloween Parade,"] ''Rutland Herald'' (Oct. 24, 2009).</ref>
The [[Vermont State Fair]] has been an annual event every September at the state fairgrounds.
Rutland's reputation within Vermont is that of a city in decline, and is referred to derisively as "RutVegas" by residents because of the long strip of Main Street (the US Route 4/7 overlap), which bisects the city and contains many big box stores, car dealerships, and various run-down businesses.<ref>Flagg, Kathryn. [http://www.7dvt.com/2012rutland "Leaving RutVegas"]. ''Seven Days''. February 1, 2012.</ref>
==Education== [[File:RutlandHighSchool2.jpg|thumb|right|Rutland High School]] Public schools are managed by [[Rutland City School District]]. These are: *[[Rutland High School]] and Rutland Middle School *Rutland Intermediate School *Northwest Primary School *Northeast Primary School The district also runs the [[Stafford Technical Center]].
Private schools include the Catholic Christ the King School (elementary) and [[Mount Saint Joseph Academy (Rutland, Vermont)|Mount Saint Joseph Academy]] (secondary), and the Rutland Area Christian School. The city is also home to two colleges, The [[College of St. Joseph]] in Vermont (formerly called College of Saint Joseph the Provider), and [[Community College of Vermont]] (CCV).
==Media== The city's print news comes from the Pulitzer Prize-winning{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} daily ''[[Rutland Herald]]''. The weekly newspaper ''Green Mountain Outlook'' is also published in Rutland.
There are seven radio stations licensed to Rutland: *88.7 FM [[WRVT]] (public radio) *90.5 [[WFTF]] *94.5 [[WDVT]] (classic hits) *97.1 [[WZRT]] (Top 40) *98.1 [[WJJR]] (Adult Contemporary hits) *105.3 [[WJEN]] (country music) *1380 AM [[WSYB]]
[[PBS]] affiliate [[WVER]], channel 9, broadcasts from Rutland.
==Hospital== [[Rutland Regional Medical Center]] is Vermont's second-largest health care facility,{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} with 188 inpatient beds and 120 physicians.
==Sister city== {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Ishidoriya, Iwate]], [[Japan]]
Since 1986, Rutland hosts an annual exchange called the Rutland Ishidoriya Student Exchange (R.I.S.E), selecting students from grades 8-11 to send to Ishidoriya, Japan. All of the money used to support the exchange is from fundraising. In exchange, 5 students from Ishidoriya come to Rutland the January after the Rutland ambassadors return each year.

'''Barre''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ær|i}} is a city in [[Washington County, Vermont|Washington County]], [[Vermont]], in the [[United States]]. As of the [[United States Census, 2010|2010 census]], the city population was 9,052.<ref>[http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?src=bkmk American Fact Finder. U.S. Census Bureau. Retrieved 3 February 2012.]</ref> Barre City is almost completely surrounded by [[Barre (town), Vermont|Barre (town)]], [[Vermont]], which is incorporated separately from the City of Barre.
Barre is often twinned with nearby [[Montpelier, Vermont|Montpelier]] in local media and businesses. It is the main city in the Barre Micropolitan area which, at 59,564 residents, is the 3rd largest in Vermont (after [[Burlington, Vermont|Burlington]] and [[Rutland (city), Vermont|Rutland]]). Barre itself is the largest city in [[Washington County, Vermont|Washington County]], and is the 4th largest city and the 10th largest municipality in Vermont.
[[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s movie ''[[The Trouble With Harry]]'' was premiered at the Paramount Theater in Barre on September 27, 1955.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0048750/ Internet Movie Database entry, The Trouble with Harry], accessed May 14, 2011</ref><ref>[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/1902040372.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Jun+26%2C+1960&author=&pub=Boston+Globe+(1960-1979)&desc=Hitchcock+Believes+Film-Going+Public+Has+Matured&pqatl=google Newspaper article, Hitchcock Believes Film-Going Public Has Matured], Boston Globe, June 26, 1960</ref>
==History== {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2010}} [[Image:City Hall and Park, Barre, VT.jpg|thumb|left|City Hall and park in c. 1910]]
On November 6, 1780, the land was granted to William Williams and 64 others. Originally called Wildersburgh, it included what is today both the town and city of Barre. It was first settled in 1788 by John Goldsbury and Samuel Rodgers, together with their families. But dissatisfied with the name Wildersburgh, citizens renamed the town after [[Isaac Barré]], a champion of the [[American Colonies]]. In 1895, 4.0 square miles (10.4 km<sup>2</sup>) within the town was set off and incorporated as the separate city.
===Granite industry=== [[Image:BarreGranite.jpg|thumb|left|Sample of the [[Barre Granite]] from the E. L. Smith Quarry of the Rock of Ages Stone Company, [[Graniteville, Vermont]]]] Barre is the self-proclaimed "[[Granite]] Center of the World." Initially established with the discovery of vast granite deposits at Millstone Hill soon after the [[War of 1812]], the granite industry and the city itself saw a boom with the arrival of the [[railroad]]. The fame of this vast deposit of granite, which some geologists say is {{convert|4|mi|km}} long, {{convert|2|mi|km}} wide and {{convert|10|mi|km}} deep, soon spread to [[Europe]] and [[Canada]]. Large numbers of people migrated to Barre from [[Italy]], [[Scotland]], [[Spain]], [[Scandinavia]], [[Greece]], [[Lebanon]], Canada and a number of other countries. The population increased from 2,060 in 1880, to 6,790 in 1890, to 10,000 in 1894. By the turn of the century, Barre was noted as the state's most diverse municipality.
The Italian immigrants in particular brought a radical, largely [[anarchist]] labor movement to Barre. They were originally affiliated with the [[Socialist Labor Party]] before affiliating with the [[Industrial Workers of the World]], and in 1916 and in 1929 the city elected a [[Socialist Party of America|Socialist Party]] candidate as mayor of Barre. The old [[Socialist Labor Party Hall]] of the radicals is still standing, and was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2000.
"Barre Gray" granite is sought after worldwide for its fine grain, even texture, and superior weather resistance. Many sculpture artists prefer it for outdoor sculpture.<ref>Rich, Jack C., (1988) ''Materials and Methods of Sculpture,'' Dover Publications</ref> In 1936 the granite quarry in Barre carved out a 35 ton cross from one section of stone in the quarry.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=lNsDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA573&dq=Popular+Science+1936+plane+%22Popular+Mechanics%22&hl=en&ei=YQxKTqCgIeSDsgK6xpzSCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Popular%20Science%201936%20plane%20%22Popular%20Mechanics%22&f=true "Thirty-Five Ton Granite Cross from One Piece of Stone" ''Popular Mechanics'', April 1936] article bottom of page 573</ref>
[[Hope Cemetery]] in Barre displays extensive examples of the sculptors' art.
==Geography and climate== According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of 4.0 square miles (10.4 km<sup>2</sup>), all land. Barre is drained by the Stevens Branch River and [[Jail Branch River]], [[tributary|tributaries]] of the [[Winooski River]].
The city is served by [[Interstate 89]], [[U.S. Route 302]], [[Vermont Route 14]] and [[Vermont Route 62]]. It is bordered by the town of [[Berlin, Vermont|Berlin]] to the west, but is otherwise surrounded by the separate town of [[Barre (town), Vermont|Barre]].

==Demographics== {{USCensusPop | 1850= 1845 | 1860= 1839 | 1870= 1882 | 1880= 2060 | 1890= 6812 | 1900= 8448 | 1910= 10734 | 1920= 10008 | 1930= 11307 | 1940= 10909 | 1950= 10922 | 1960= 10387 | 1970= 10209 | 1980= 9824 | 1990= 9482 | 2000= 9291 | 2010= 9052 | estyear= | estimate= }}
As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 9,291 people, 4,220 households, and 2,253 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 2,309.4 people per square mile (892.4/km<sup>2</sup>). There were 4,477 housing units at an average density of 1,112.8 per square mile (430.0/km<sup>2</sup>). The racial makeup of the city was 97.40% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 0.48% [[African American (U.S. Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.38% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.52% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.01% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 0.32% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 0.89% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 1.68% of the population.
There were 4,220 households out of which 26.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 37.0% were couples living together and joined in either [[marriage]] or [[Civil Union|civil union]], 12.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 46.6% were non-families. 39.2% of all households were made up of individuals and 16.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.14 and the average family size was 2.86.
In the city the population was spread out with 22.4% under the age of 18, 7.9% from 18 to 24, 29.5% from 25 to 44, 27.0% from 45 to 69, and 91.1% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females there were 86.5 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 82.6 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $30,393, and the median income for a family was $42,660. Males had a median income of $33,175 versus $20,319 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $18,724. About 9.9% of families and 13.0% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 16.2% of those under age 18 and 12.6% of those age 65 or over.
==Government== The mayor of Barre is Thom Lauzon.<ref>[http://www.barrecity.org/index.asp?Type=B_DIR&SEC={0E85789B-B1EB-4F05-B8F0-15F8BA08E2F7} City officials], Barre. Accessed 2008-02-05.</ref> Barre City has a [[Mayor–council government#Weak-mayor form|"weak mayor"]] form of government, and mayors serve two-year terms, with elections held in March. The city is divided into three wards, and each ward elects two members of the [[city council]]. Councilors serve staggered two-year terms, so one council seat from each ward is up for election every March.<ref>Annual Report, City of Barre, Vermont, Fiscal Year July 1, 2005 to June 30, 2006</ref>
Barre City also elects a full-time [[City clerk]] and [[City treasurer|treasurer]]. The current Clerk and Treasurer is Carolyn S. Dawes.<ref>[http://www.barrecity.org/index.asp?Type=B_BASIC&SEC={30739B2F-F67C-44EF-B4F2-CAE6D9C2E652} Contact information, Barre City Clerk], City of Barre web site, accessed May 15, 2011</ref>
The city of Barre employs a full-time [[city manager]]. Steven Mackenzie, a former member of the city council, currently holds this position.<ref>[http://www.cvmc.org/interior.php/pid/1/sid/4/tid/116 Board of Directors biography, Steven Mackenzie], Central Vermont Hospital web site, accessed May 15, 2011</ref>
==Sports== {{main|Vermont Frost Heaves}}
A [[Premier Basketball League]] (PBL) team, the [[Vermont Frost Heaves]], played its games in Barre at the Barre Auditorium and at the Memorial Auditorium in [[Burlington, Vermont|Burlington]], [[Vermont]]. The team was originally owned by [[Sports Illustrated]] writer [[Alexander Wolff]]. A local group later assumed ownership and operated the Heaves until the team ceased operations in late 2010 and subjected its players to a dispersal draft.
The [[Vermont Mountaineers]], a collegiate summer baseball team which belongs to the [[New England Collegiate Baseball League]], plays its home games at nearby Montpelier Recreation Field.

Accessed 2007-11-01.</ref> ([[county seat]]){{GR|6}} of [[Orleans County, Vermont|Orleans County]], [[Vermont]], [[United States]]. As of the 2010 Census, the city population was 4,589. The city contains the largest population of any municipality in the county, yet encompasses the smallest area.
==History== In 1753, the [[Abenaki]]s brought the ransomed [[John Stark]] down [[Lake Memphremagog]] and came ashore where Newport is now. They then traveled southeast to his home in [[New Hampshire]].
[[Rogers' Rangers]] were forced to retreat through the county following their attack on [[Saint-François-du-Lac, Quebec|Saint-Francis, Quebec]] in 1759. To confound their avenging pursuers, they split up on the east shore of Lake Memphremagog. One group followed the [[Clyde River (Vermont)|Clyde River]] east. Another followed the [[Barton River]] south.<ref>{{cite book | title=Sketches of Orleans, Vermont |year=1985 |isbn=0-9610860-2-5 |publisher=Mempremagog Press |author=Darrell Hoyt}}, page 1</ref>
Newport as a settlement began in 1793.<ref>''Columbia-Lippincott Gazeteer''. (New York: Columbia University Press, 1952) p. 1314</ref> The village was first called Pickeral Point, but later renamed Lake Bridge for its location at the head of Lake Memphremagog.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=OcoMAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA9&ots=cUndZkVSIF&dq=coolidge%20mansfield%20history%20description%20new%20england%201859&pg=PA862#v=onepage&q=&f=false Austin J. Coolidge & John B. Mansfield, ''A History and Description of New England;'' Boston, Massachusetts 1859]</ref>
In the early 19th century, the women of pioneer Calvin Arnold's household, refused to live in the Arnold house near what is now Clyde Pond, because of depredations by the [[Native Americans of the United States|Indians]].<ref name="elect">{{cite book | author = Wheeler, Scott |title = The Man Who Helped Electrify the Jay Peak Ski Lift | publisher = Northland Journal | year = February 2008}}</ref>
In 1816, part of the former town of Salem, was annexed to Newport town, and is now part of the city.<ref>[http://www.virtualvermont.com/towns/derby.html]</ref>
The railroad reached the village in 1863.<ref name="nj100613">{{Cite news | first=C. D. | last=Robinson | title=The Memphremagog House and ST. Albans Raid | url=| work=Newport Express and Standard, 1929 | publisher=Northland Journal | location=Newport, Vermont | pages= 10 | date=June 2010 | accessdate=}}</ref>
The city had a scare when they received news of the [[St. Albans Raid]] during the American Civil War. They thought these raids might repeat throughout the state but particularly at the south end of the lake. The militia was turned out. The ferry from Magog was met with determined looking armed men, much to the captain's surprise, who had heard nothing about the raid. Armed [[Norwich University]] students were shipped in by train. Nothing happened and everyone was sent home in a few days.<ref name="nj100613"/>
In 1868, the Lake Bridge settlement was incorporated as the Village of Newport.
It became a busy [[lumber]] town. The firm of Prouty & Miller, a [[lumbering]] firm, was started in 1865. With the end of the lumbering concentration in Vermont, it went out of business in the 1980s.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=uTBCXqOou0YC&pg=PA216&lpg=PA216&dq=%22prouty+and+miller%22+newport+vermont&source=web&ots=AJNK5pkDYR&sig=OeN9H6kWbns503d-ErrwE3dg6R0&hl=en#PPA6,M1 Vermont Almanac] accessed March 2, 2008</ref> [[Image:Railroad Station, Newport, VT.jpg|thumb|left|Railroad station and steamboat ''Lady of the Lake'' in 1908]]
The ''Lady of the Lake'' [[steamboat|steam excursion/ferry boat]] started operating in 1867. It stopped operations in 1917. This is used as Newport's logo.
In 1868, a [[livery stable]] that would ultimately grow to 100 horses, started operating behind a hotel, several blocks from the railway station.<ref>{{cite book | author = Gibson, Peggy Day |title = The voice of harness racing | publisher = the Chronicle | date = August 6, 2008}}</ref>
In 1873, the Bellevue Hotel was built to accommodate 75, and later, 100 guests. It was renamed the Newport House by 1891. It was demolished in 1973.<ref>{{Cite journal |first=Emily M. |last=Nelson |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2009 |month=December |title=The History of the Newport House |journal=Vermont's Northland Journal |volume=8 |issue=9 |pages=8, 9 |url=}}</ref>
The Newport Wharf Light was a tower built on Lake Memphremagog in 1879. It has since been demolished.<ref>[http://www.lhdepot.com/database/uniquelighthouse.cfm?value=1734 Lighthouses at Lighthouse Depot ... Lighthouse Explorer Database ... Newport Wharf Light]</ref>
The current county courthouse was built in 1886.<ref name="mark9">Historic marker #9, Newport, Vermont</ref> That was the year that the legislature moved the shire town here.<ref name="autogenerated4">{{cite book | author = Young, Darlene |title = A history of Barton Vermont | publisher = Crystal Lake Falls Historical Association|year = 1998}}</ref>
By the late 19th century, the [[Boston & Maine Railroad|Boston & Maine]] and [[Central Vermont Railway|Central Vermont]] [[railroad]]s were routed through Lake Bridge and the small village experienced a population boom. [[Image:The Memphremagog House, Newport, VT.jpg|thumb|right|Memphremagog House c. 1880s, built in 1838 and burned in 1907]]
The now-historic [[Goodrich Memorial Library]] was built in 1899.<ref>[http://www.goodrichlibrary.org/history.htm Goodrich Memorial Library website]</ref>
The Memphremagog Hotel burned in 1907.<ref name="nj0901">{{Cite journal |first=Scott |last=Wheeler |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2009 |month=January |title=Boxing, Singing, and Riding the Rails into the Page of Newport's History |journal=Vermont's Northland Journal |volume=7 |issue=10 |pages=10 |url=}}</ref> [[Image:Main Street, Newport, VT.jpg|thumb|left|Main Street in 1908]]
In 1917, the city of Newport was formed from portions of the towns of [[Newport (town), Vermont|Newport]] (former village of Newport) and [[Derby, Vermont|Derby]] (former village of West Derby). It was organized on March 5, 1918.
The current federal courthouse was built in 1904. Then, it included the post office.<ref name="mark9"/>
In 1917, the city paved Main Street. By 1930, 4,000 motor vehicles a day, during the summer, traveled the street.<ref name="mark9"/>
In 1932, the city had a [[poor farm]] for the indigent.<ref>{{cite news | first=Scott | last=Wheeler | title=Life Down on the Community Poor Farm - Part 2 | url=| work= | publisher=Northland Journal | location=Derby, Vermont | pages= 27 | date=May 2012 | accessdate=}}</ref>
In August 1942, a single-engined [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] training plane crashed into the lake near the west shore near the city, killing the only occupant, the pilot.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Salvage Operations on Crashed Plane Now Underway | url=| work= | publisher=the November 13, 1943 Newport Daily Express as quoted in the Northland Journal | location=Derby, Vermont | pages= 29–30 | date=September 2008 | accessdate=}}</ref><!---"near Strawberry Acres"--->
Between 1936 and 1953, the International Club in Newport had the largest dance floor in [[New England]], {{convert|220|by|60|ft}}.<ref>[http://www.oldstonehousemuseum.org/PDF/oshspring06.pdf]</ref> It was capable of holding 2,000 dancers. Various performers stopped to entertain while en route between [[Boston]] and [[Montreal]] on the railroad. These included: [[Louis Armstrong]], [[Charlie Barnet]], [[Les Brown (bandleader)|Les Brown]], [[Cab Calloway]], [[Rosemary Clooney]], the Dorsey Brothers, [[Jimmy Dorsey|Jimmy]] and [[Tommy Dorsey|Tommy]]; [[Stan Kenton]], [[Kay Kyser]], [[Gene Krupa]], [[Glenn Miller]], [[Tony Pastor (bandleader)|Tony Pastor]], and [[Louis Prima]].<ref>{{cite book | author = Old Stone House Museum |title = Big band dance to honor Korean War veterans | publisher = the Chronicle | date = June 29, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = Goyette, Ray |title = Reader Reflects on the International Club | publisher = Vermont's Northland Journal | month = August | year = 2006}}</ref>
From its founding, Newport's population plateaued around 5,000 people until 1950 when it started dropping. It reached bottom in 1990 at 4,434. In 2010 the population dropped from the 2000 census, and it still had not reached its 1950 high which was 5,217. In 2003, the Newport-headquartered Citizens Utility was sold and divided up among Great Bay Hydro and [[Vermont Electric Cooperative]].<ref name="elect">{{cite book | author = Wheeler, Scott |title = The Man Who Helped Electrify the Jay Peak Ski Area | publisher = Northland Journal | month = February | year = 2008}}</ref>
The last passenger train left Newport in 1965.<ref name="nj0901">{{Cite journal |first=Scott |last=Wheeler |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2009 |month=January |title=Boxing, Singing, and Riding the Rails into the Page of Newport's History |journal=Vermont's Northland Journal |volume=7 |issue=10 |pages=17 |url=}}</ref>
The city sold its [[Newport State Airport (Vermont)|airport]] to the state of Vermont in the 1970s.<ref>{{Cite journal |first=Duane |last=Wright |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2009 |month=September |title=Up, Up and Away with Cecil Wright and His Flying Machines |journal=vermont's Northland Journal |volume=8 |issue=6 |pages=8 |url=}}</ref>
The [[Vermont Teddy Bear Company]] once had a plant within the city.<ref>[http://www.vermonteddybear.com/Gifts-Ideas/default/EMPLOYMENT.page Career Opportunities]</ref> A [[Columbia Forest Products]] plant once employed about 100 workers.<ref name="The Associated Press">{{cite book | author = The Associated Press |title = 54 workers laid off in Newport | publisher = Burlington Free Press | date = December 4, 2008}}</ref>
A local subsidiary of [[Willy_Bogner,_Jr.#Life_and_work|an international ski clothing manufacturer]] once employed 30 workers.<!---Bogners--><ref>[http://www.manta.com/coms2/dnbcompany_dhgdmg]</ref> It closed in 2011.
==Geography== According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of 7.6 square miles (19.7 km<sup>2</sup>), of which 6.0 square miles (15.6 km<sup>2</sup>) is land and 1.6 square miles (4.1 km<sup>2</sup>) (20.87%) is water. The city surrounds the southern shore of [[Lake Memphremagog]]. Three of the four major rivers in the county empty into the lake here: the [[Clyde River (Vermont)|Clyde]], [[Barton River|Barton]], and the [[Black River (Lake Memphremagog)|Black]].
Newport borders the towns of [[Coventry, Vermont|Coventry]] to the south, [[Newport (town), Vermont|Newport]] to the west, and [[Derby, Vermont|Derby]] to the north and east. {{clear}}

==Demographics== {{USCensusPop |1920= 4976 |1930= 5094 |1940= 4902 |1950= 5217 |1960= 5019 |1970= 4664 |1980= 4756 |1990= 4434 |2000= 5005 |2010= 4589 |footnote=<center>[http://www.census.gov/prod/www/abs/decennial/ U.S. Decennial Census]</center> }} As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2010, there were 4,589 people,<!--remainder of this sentence is based on 2000 census--> 2,086 households, and 1,191 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 830.0 people per square mile (320.5/km<sup>2</sup>). There were 2,342 housing units at an average density of 388.4 per square mile (150.0/km<sup>2</sup>). The racial makeup of the city was 96.14% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 0.76% [[African American (U.S. Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.62% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.62% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.22% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 1.64% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 1.28% of the population. 33% were of French Canadian and French ancestry, 16% English, and 14% Irish.<ref>http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Newport_(city),_Vermont&action=edit</ref>
There were 2,086 households out of which 26.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 41.0% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 12.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 42.9% were non-families. 35.5% of all households were made up of individuals and 16.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.20 and the average family size was 2.84.
In the city the population was distributed by age with 22.2% under 18, 8.3% from 18 to 24, 27.1% from 25 to 44, 23.1% from 45 to 64, and 19.3% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females there were 97.4 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.7 males.
In 2013, about 31% of adults in the area were obese. This was the highest in the state.<ref>{{Cite news | first=Tena | last=Starr | title=Three-fourths of region's adults are overweight | url=| work= | newspaper=The Chronicle | location=Barton, Vermont | pages= 1A | date=September 18, 2013 | id= | accessdate=}}</ref>
==Economy==
===Personal income=== The median income for a household in the city was $25,544, and the median income for a family was $34,922. Males had a median income of $33,810 versus $19,787 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $20,054. About 13.0% of families and 18.2% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 25.4% of those under age 18 and 5.4% of those age 65 or over.
The per capita income is the highest in Orleans County. The income ranks it 108 out of 282 census areas in Vermont.
===Industry=== Poulin Grain ships its farm feed products to customers in New England and upstate New York.<ref>[http://www.poulingrain.com/pages/838/Dealer_Locator.htm?PHPSESSID=acd40410540ed7efca1f5f1df993640d Poulin Grain - Dealer Locator]</ref> It employs about 50 workers. The plant is producing feed 24 hours a day, seven days a week.<ref>[http://www.travelthekingdom.com/geotourism/pressroom/vermontbiz.com_vbm_online_article.cfm_articleID=2839.pdf Vermont Business Magazine]</ref>
A [[Columbia Forest Products]] plant employs about 100 workers.<ref name="The Associated Press"/>
There is a call center employing 120 people.<!--Catalog Retail Marketing International = CRMI--><ref>[http://www.manta.com/coms2/dnbcompany_dg203]</ref><ref>the Chronicle, September 3, 2008, page 11, "We're on a real growth path right now"</ref>
[[Mine Safety Appliances|MSA]] manufactures military combat helmets.<ref>[http://www.newportvermontdailyexpress.com/content/view/234863/]</ref>
===Health industry=== [[North Country Hospital]] is located in the city. The hospital is the city's largest employer, employing 605 people.<ref>[http://www.nchsi.org/getpage.php?name=index North Country Hospital information]</ref>
[[Orleans-Essex Visiting Nurses Association and Hospice]] employs 100 people locally.
The [[Northeast Kingdom Human Services]] aids mental health needs.
Social services are provided in part by the [[Northeast Kingdom Community Action]] located here and in other Northeast Kingdom sites.
===Tourism=== A commercial [[ice fishing]] [[Fishing tournament|derby]] has been held in February since 2004. In 2010, there were 920 participants.<ref>{{Cite news | first=Richard | last=Creaser | title=Northeast Kingdom's lakes ripe for ice fishing | url=| work= | newspaper=[[The Chronicle (Barton, Vermont)|The Chronicle]] | location=Barton, Vermont | pages= 12 | date=February 2, 2011 | accessdate=}}</ref>
The only [[Soap Box Derby]] in Vermont is held in the city annually. The winner represents the state in the nationals.<ref>The Chronicle, July 1, 2009, page 21, "Mosholder takes top spot in derby," Dr. Turcotte</ref>
The local [[Rotary International|Rotary]] has held an annual music festival involving county high schools since 1947.<ref>{{Cite news | first= | last= | title=Rotary holds sixty-ninth annual music festival | url=| work= | newspaper=the Chronicle | location=Barton, Vermont | pages= 3 | date=April 10, 2013 | id= | accessdate=}}</ref>
===Non-local government=== [[Image:OrleansCountyCourtJail.JPG|thumb|Orleans County courthouse in Newport]] Located in the city is the [[Northern State Correctional Facility]], the Newport Court, Reparative Services, and the Vermont Correctional Industries.
==City government==
Municipal offices are located in the former National Guard Armory, 222 Main Street, Newport.
Elected government consists of 4 aldermen with staggered two years terms and a mayor.<ref>[http://www.newportvermont.org/directory.htm Newport, Vermont]</ref>
The city has a paid staff for tax assessment/zoning administrator, public works department, police, fire, recreation and parks, city attorney, and harbor master.
There are decision-making boards which are filled by unpaid appointees: planning commission (5 people, three year terms), harbor commission (5 people, two year terms),development review board (nine people, three year terms), and a recreation committee.<!--also a cemetery commission. not sure where that goes.--->
There are normal officers for Vermont cities and sometimes towns, except they are appointed for cities: Delinquent tax collector, town service officer, animal control, health officer, tree warden, weigher of coal<!---huh?--->, inspector of wood and shingles, representative to NVDA (Northeastern Vermont Development Association) board, representative to EDC board (Vermont Economic Development Authority)<!---I think they are the same--->, and [[Fence Viewer]]s.
* Budget (proposed 2007-2008) - $2,479,193<ref name="2007rpt">{{cite book | author = |title = Annual City & School Report, City of Newport, Vermont | publisher = Memphremagog Press, Inc., Newport, Vermont | year = 2007}}</ref>
===Officials=== The city is governed under the [[mayor-council government|mayor-council system]]. Its mayor is Paul Monette, and the council is composed of Richard Baraw, Tim de la Bruere, Dennis Chenette, and John Wilson.<ref>[http://www.newportvermont.org/citycouncil.php Newport City Council], Newport, 2007. Accessed 2009-03-26.</ref> The city clerk/treasurer is James D. Johnson,<ref>[http://www.newportvermont.org/cityclerktreas.php City Clerk/Treasurer], Newport, 2008. Accessed 2009-03-26.</ref> and the [[city manager]] is John O. Ward.<ref>[http://www.newportvermont.org/citymgr.php City Manager], Newport, 2007. Accessed 2009-03-26.</ref>

===Elections=== Fifty-four percent of those registered, voted in the 2008 general election. This was the lowest turnout in the county. <ref>{{cite book | author = |title = Voter turnout | publisher = the Chronicle | date = November 5, 2008}}</ref>
==Education== Newport has two public schools: an elementary school, Newport City Elementary, and a high school, [[North Country Union High School]]. There is one private school, the United Christian Academy. It was formerly home to Sacred Heart School in the Burlington Roman Catholic Diocese School District,<ref>[http://www.vermontcatholic.org/CatholicSchools/Burlington]</ref> but closed in fall of 2007.
===School districts=== The city has a school board that governs the operation of Newport Elementary.
School Board directors include Leo Willey (chair), Corinna Lancaster (vice chair), Marcy Miller, Patrick Haugwitz, and Phil Laramie.
The budget for the Newport City Elementary School was $4,435,765 in 2007.
In addition, the city belongs to [[North Country Supervisory Union]] with members from nearby towns. They operate the [[North Country Union High School]] and the North Country Union Junior High School. The supervisor hired by this union board supervises the town school, as well as the union schools.
* Member, North Country Union High School Board - Tim DelaBruere (2010), Richard Cartee (2008) and James Privee (2009)<ref name="2007rpt" />
===Higher education=== Newport is home to a branch of the [[Community College of Vermont]] which enrolls nearly 300 students.<ref>[http://www.ccv.edu/about/facts/index.html Facts & Figures - Community College of Vermont<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It awards an [[Associate's Degree]] for these undergraduate studies.
==Infrastructure==
===Transportation===
====Major routes==== [[File:US5-Newport.jpg|thumb|250px|U.S. Route 5 in Newport at the junction of [[Vermont Route 191]] heading toward [[Interstate 91]].]] * [[Image:US 5.svg|20px]] [[U.S. Route 5]] - connecting Coventry to the south, Derby to the north and east * [[Image:Vermont 14.svg|20px]] [[VT Route 14]] - connecting the Town of Coventry * [[Image:Vermont 100.svg|25px]] [[VT Route 100]] - connecting the Town of Newport * [[Image:Vermont 105.svg|25px]] [[VT Route 105]] - connecting the Town of Newport (concurrent with route 100), and the town of Derby (concurrent with route 191) * [[Image:Vermont 191.svg|25px]] [[VT Route 191]] - "Access Road", connects I-91, Exit 27, to the city of Newport
The city has six stoplights, which is most of the stoplights in the county. Five are on Route 5.
====Major bridges==== There are three major bridges over the South Bay of Lake Memphremagog, two of which connect two parts of the city, the former village of Newport with the former village of West Derby. Those two are the bridge on Route 5, and the "Long Bridge" connecting Route 5 to Mt. Vernon Street. Plans are underway to replace this latter bridge starting in 2012. It will cost about $5.26 million. The state will pay 90%, the city, the remainder.<ref>{{Cite news | first=Joseph | last=Gresser | title=Long Bridge to close for long time | url=| work= | publisher=the Chronicle | location=Barton, Vermont | pages= 8 | date=21 July 2010 | accessdate=}}</ref>
The final bridge is the trestle for the railway.
====Local community public and private transportation==== The RCT ([[Rural Community Transportation]]), a non-profit organization, runs out of Saint Johnsbury and services Caledonia and two other counties, including Orleans.<ref name="2007rpt" /> For general use, there are four buses north and south during the week from west Newport city to Derby, and two buses each way on Saturday. The fare is US 25 cents.<ref>{{cite book | author = |title = Rural Community Transportation Large Format Bus Schedule - The Highlander (Newport/Derby/Derby Line | publisher = | year = 2008}}</ref>
====Railroads==== [[Washington County Railroad (1980)|Washington County Railroad]] (known by the [[reporting mark]] WACR) - In 2007 WACR was awarded a 30 year contract by the State of Vermont to operate the rail line between White River Junction and Newport. Today the only regular service on this line is freight traffic.
[[Montreal, Maine and Atlantic Railway]] (known by the [[reporting mark]] MMA) - The MMA operates the line running northwest through North Troy and eventually on to [[Farnham, Quebec]]. It interchanges freight traffic with the WACR at Newport yard, just south of town.
A rail line, which was part of the [[Quebec Central Railway]], once ran east of Lake Memphremagog up to [[Lennoxville, Quebec]], but it has been abandoned and the right-of-way has been converted into a mixed-use bicycle and walking path.
====Airport==== The city is served by the Newport State Airport.<ref>[http://vimeo.com/30271136 Newport State Airport]</ref> It contains two runways of {{convert|4000|ft}} each 05-23, and 18-36.
===Sewage=== The city discharged an average of {{convert|908917|gal}} of treated wastewater daily into the Clyde River in 2003-04.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.anr.state.vt.us/dec//waterq/planning/docs/pl_basin17.assessment_report.pdf |title=Basin 17:Lake Memphremagog Watershed Assessment Report |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2006-03 |year= |month= |work= |publisher=Vermont Agency of Natural Resources,Department of Environmental Conservation, Water Quality Division |pages=34 |archiveurl= |archivedate= }}</ref>

Bordered by the towns of [[Ferrisburgh, Vermont|Ferrisburgh]], [[Panton, Vermont|Panton]] and [[Waltham, Vermont|Waltham]], as of the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]] the city population was 2,588, the smallest of Vermont's nine cities in terms of population (though the city of [[Winooski, Vermont|Winooski]] covers a smaller area). It was the first city chartered in the state.<ref>[http://www.historicvermont.org/sites/html/history.html]</ref>
==History== [[Image:Vergennes, Charles Gravier comte de.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Charles Gravier, comte de Vergennes]] Vergennes, first settled in 1766 by Donald MacIntosh, was established in 1788,<ref name=cityweb/> the only one of Vermont's cities not to have been first chartered as a town or independent village. Instead, portions of the pre-existing towns of [[New Haven, Vermont|New Haven]], [[Panton, Vermont|Panton]] and [[Ferrisburg, Vermont|Ferrisburg]] where they intersected at the Otter Creek Falls were drawn off to create Vergennes.<ref name=cityweb/> It is the smallest city (by population) in Vermont.
The city is named for [[Charles Gravier, comte de Vergennes|Charles Gravier]], [[Count|Comte]] de Vergennes.<ref>City of Vergennes. (n.d.). [http://www.vergennes.org/ ''City of Vergennes.''] Retrieved January 2, 2010.</ref> His hatred of the British and his desire for revenge for the [[French and Indian war]], made him support the American colonists during the [[American Revolutionary War]] and send arms and troops to the revolutionary cause. He gave in to the demand of Beaumarchais to secretly procure arms and volunteers to the Americans. As directed by [[Louis XVI]], Gravier established a dummy company through which the Americans received nearly 80% of their military supplies. It was also Gravier who negotiated the [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|1783 Treaty of Paris]], which formally brought the Revolutionary War to a close.
Here, [[Thomas Macdonough]] built and armed the fleet that would defeat the British on Lake Champlain during the [[War of 1812]]. The Monkton Iron Company (which was at the time the largest iron works in the colonies) manufactured the fittings for Macdonough's fleet, as well as most of the cannon shot used by the army in the north. The ore used was mined in nearby [[Monkton, Vermont|Monkton]].
The motive for a city form of municipal government is said to have been to provide a vision for building the area as an industrial center. The Otter Creek Falls and close access to the [[Lake Champlain]] waterway was thought to be a fertile place for commercial growth.
Industry boomed in the late nineteenth century, in particular, shipping connected to the Champlain Canal and wood-finishing related to lumber imported from Canada. As railways supplanted the canal system, manufacturing declined. A railroad spur from Ferrisburgh to the base of the falls proved a failure, with grades too steep for practical operations.
Commercial decline continued in the twentieth century, narrowing down to a few surviving companies; as the twenty-first opened, a group of civic boosters and merchants improved the downtown area along Main Street. The resultant 'boutique Vergennes', catering to tourists and transients, is hampered by centralization of land ownership and resultant escalation of commercial rents.
==Geography== [[Image:HPIM0003.JPG|thumb|right|Vergennes City Hall, Opera House, and Police Station]] According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of 2.5 square miles (6.5 km<sup>2</sup>), of which 2.4 square miles (6.2 km<sup>2</sup>) is land and 0.1 square mile (0.3 km<sup>2</sup>) (4.00%) is water.
The city's borders form a rectangle, nearly a square. [[Otter Creek (Vermont)|Otter Creek]] flows north through the town. In the middle of town is a 37-foot waterfall, with a large basin which occasionally floods.
==Demographics== [[Image:Vergenneschurch.JPG|thumb|left|St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Main Street next to the City Hall]]
As of the census{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 2,741 people, 979 households, and 632 families residing in the city. The population density was 1,141.1 people per square mile (441.0/km<sup>2</sup>). There were 1,032 housing units at an average density of 429.6 per square mile (166.0/km<sup>2</sup>). The racial makeup of the city was 93.43% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 2.01% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 0.22% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.36% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.04% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 1.06% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 2.88% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 2.92% of the population.
There were 979 households out of which 34.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 48.8% were married couples living together, 11.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 35.4% were non-families. 28.2% of all households were made up of individuals and 12.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.47 and the average family size was 3.02.
In the city the age distribution of the population shows 28.4% under the age of 18, 13.1% from 18 to 24, 27.8% from 25 to 44, 19.3% from 45 to 64, and 11.3% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 33 years. For every 100 females there were 100.4 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.8 males.
==Economy== [[Image:Bixby Library.jpg|thumb|right|The Bixby Memorial Free Library]]
===Personal income=== The median income for a household in the city was $37,763, and the median income for a family was $48,155. Males had a median income of $33,669 versus $20,527 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $15,465. About 8.1% of families and 17.0% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 8.5% of those under age 18 and 16.0% of those age 65 or over.
===Manufacturing=== The [[Goodrich Corporation]] employs approximately 800 people although Goodrich has been since bought out by UTC Aerospace.
==Schools== Vergennes has four schools: Vergennes Union Elementary School, [[Vergennes Union High School]], Champlain Valley Christian School, and Northlands [[Job Corps]] Center, the former Weeks School, which served as an orphanage and juvenile delinquent home until the late 1970s, in the same facility.
Vergennes Union High School also offers an alternative public program, the [[Walden Project]], available to area students.
==Culture== The city features the [[Vergennes Opera House]], which has weekly events involving the community and special guests, bands, singers, politicians and theater groups. The city has a library, the Bixby Memorial Free Library.<ref>[http://www.bixbylibrary.org/ Bixby Memorial Free Library]</ref>

'''St. Albans City''' <ref>[http://www.leg.state.vt.us/statutes/fullsection.cfm?Title=24&Chapter=001&Section=00007 Title 24, Part I, Chapter 1, §7], Vermont Statutes. Accessed 2007-11-01.</ref> ([[county seat]]){{GR|6}} [[Franklin County, Vermont|Franklin County]], [[Vermont]], in the [[United States]]. At the [[United States Census, 2010|2010 census]], the city population was 6,918. St Albans City is surrounded by [[St. Albans (town), Vermont|St. Albans]] [[New England town|town]], which is incorporated separately from the city of St. Albans. The city and area are part of the [[Burlington-South Burlington, VT Metropolitan Statistical Area]].
==History== [[File:Main Street Looking North, St. Albans, VT.jpg|thumb|left|Main Street in 1909]] One of the [[New Hampshire grants]], St. Albans was chartered by Colonial Governor [[Benning Wentworth]] on August 17, 1763 to Stephen Pomeroy and 63 others. Named after [[St. Albans]] in [[Hertfordshire]], [[England]], it was first settled during the [[American Revolution|Revolution]] by Jesse Welden. The war, however, delayed further settlement until 1785, when many others began arriving. Farmers found the rich, dark [[loam]] suitable for [[Tillage|cultivation]], as well as for the raising of [[cattle]], [[horse]]s and [[sheep]]. [[Butter]] and [[cheese]] were produced in great quantities.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=OcoMAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA9&ots=cUndZkVSIF&dq=coolidge%20mansfield%20history%20description%20new%20england%201859&pg=PA906#v=onepage&q=&f=false Austin J. Coolidge & John B. Mansfield, ''A History and Description of New England;'' Boston, Massachusetts 1859]</ref> It also became known as "Railroad City," home to a major [[train station|depot]], operations center and repair shop of the [[Vermont and Canada Railroad]].<ref>[http://www.virtualvermont.com/towns/stalbans.html Virtual Vermont -- St. Albans]</ref> When the village was incorporated in 1859,<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=7n99eBPfOZ8C&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q=incorporated&f=false Advantages, Resources and Attractions of St. Albans, Vt., 1889]</ref> it had an [[iron]] [[foundry]], a manufacturer of [[freight car]]s, and a large number of [[mechanic]] shops.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=OcoMAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA9&ots=cUndZkVSIF&dq=coolidge%20mansfield%20history%20description%20new%20england%201859&pg=PA906#v=onepage&q=&f=false Austin J. Coolidge & John B. Mansfield, ''A History and Description of New England;'' Boston, Massachusetts 1859]</ref>
The northernmost engagement of the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], known as the [[St. Albans Raid]], occurred here on October 19, 1864. In 1902, the City of St. Albans was incorporated, comprising two square miles (518 hectares) within the town of [[St. Albans (town), Vermont|St. Albans]]. Today, it is a [[tourist destination]] noted for its [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] and [[American Craftsman|Craftsman]] style [[architecture]] built during the railroad era, when over 200 trains a day passed through.<ref>[http://www.stamuseum.com/ St. Albans Historical Society]</ref> St. Albans is a research target for [[genealogy|genealogists]], as [[Europe]]an [[immigrant]]s heading for the United States would sometimes land at [[City of Halifax|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]] or [[Montreal, Canada|Montreal]], then take a train through the border crossing here. The [[United States National Archives|National Archives]] (NARA) lists for St. Albans cover the period 1895-1954.<ref>[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~holdenclan/albans.htm Genealogical lists -- St. Albans, Vermont]</ref>
==Culture== St. Albans is called "The [[Maple Syrup]] Capital of the World," and in late April sponsors the annual Vermont [[Sugar Maple|Maple]] Festival. The festival includes many different food-related contests, as well as a footrace from [[Swanton (town), Vermont|Swanton]], 8.2 miles (13.2 km) to the north.<ref>{{cite web | title = Vermont Maple Festival | publisher = Vermont Maple Festival | url = http://www.vtmaplefestival.org/ | accessdate = 2009-08-01}}</ref>
==Geography== According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of 2.0 square miles (5.3 km<sup>2</sup>), all land. The city is surrounded by the town of [[St. Albans (town), Vermont|St. Albans]], with its lush [[arable land|farmland]] across gently rolling hills. The city is drained by Stevens Brook.
St. Albans is crossed by [[Interstate 89]], [[U.S. Route 7 in Vermont|U.S. Route 7]], as well as [[Vermont Route 36]], 38, 104 and [[Vermont Route 105|105]]. It is about {{convert|15|mi}} from Vermont's border with [[Quebec]].
==Demographics== [[File:StAHistDist.JPG|thumb|left|Saint Albans Historic District]] At the 2010 [[census]]{{GR|2}}, there were 6,918 people. In the 2000 census there were 7,650 people, 3,235 households and 1,937 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 3,768.2 per square mile (1,455.0/km<sup>2</sup>). There were 3,376 housing units at an average density of 1,662.9 per square mile (642.1/km<sup>2</sup>). The racial makeup of the city was 95.87% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 0.39% [[African American (U.S. Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 1.20% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.35% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.03% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 0.46% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 1.70% from two or more races. 0.90% of the population were [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race.
There were 3,235 households of which 31.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 43.6% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 12.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 40.1% were non-families. 31.4% of all households were made up of individuals and 12.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.35 and the average family size was 2.97.
Age distribution was 25.6% under the age of 18, 8.3% from 18 to 24, 31.8% from 25 to 44, 20.3% from 45 to 64, and 14.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 35 years. For every 100 females there were 91.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 86.2 males.
==Government== [[File:Church Street, St. Albans, VT.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Church Street in 1909]] St. Albans is governed via a mayor and city council. The city council consists of six member each elected from individual wards. The mayor is elected in a citywide vote.
==Economy==
===Personal income=== The [[median household income]] $37,221, and the median family income was $44,286. Males had a median income of $31,340 versus $23,262 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $17,853. About 8.5% of families and 9.6% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 9.2% of those under age 18 and 11.9% of those age 65 or over.
===Industry=== The [[U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services|USCIS]] has a service center in St. Albans.
==Infrastructure==
===Railways=== Saint Albans is the northern terminus of the [[Vermonter]], an all-coach train operated by [[Amtrak]], the national passenger rail system. This train operates daily from Saint Albans to and from [[Washington, D.C.]] and points between.
The train formerly continued on from Saint Albans to [[Montreal]] and was named the [[Montrealer (train)|Montrealer]], but that connection is now discontinued.
